awd_titl_txt: African American Students'  Sociocultural Experiences, Motivation, Identity and Performance in Math
awd_abstract_narration:
Research has shown that, on average, African American students perform less well on STEM standardized tests, opt out of advanced coursework despite requisite ability, and choose to major in non-STEM fields in college despite relevant preparation. This project will use a combination of a primary quantitative analysis and a supplemental qualitative analysis to examine the interrelations between African American middle school students' experiences of stigma in math, developing gender and racial identities, racial socialization experiences with adults at home and in school, and motivational constructs of competence beliefs and values in math.

Intellectual Merit: To inform efforts to broaden STEM participation among African American students, there is a need for more research using within-group designs and attending to race and gender simultaneously. The quantitative analysis will investigate this complex system of interrelations and the development over time of these dynamics, while a supplemental qualitative analysis will explore both the precise effect mechanisms at hand and qualitatively distinct intersectional effects across these pathways. The overall project represents longitudinal, multi-informant research, using in-depth interviews to supplement survey data analyses of reports from students, parents, and teachers. This project targets 6th through 8th grade, a critical developmental juncture for students in terms of formation of identity and math motivation. The combination of these techniques will ultimately reveal how race- and gender-related experiences interrelate to shape African-American early adolescents' motivation and achievement in math. 

Broader impacts: The study will advance research on African American adolescents' motivational processes and sociocultural and contextual correlates of achievement in math contexts. Moreover, this study will identify the ways in which middle school-based experiences can affect personal and contextual factors in ways that are malleable to efforts aimed at promoting high math achievement and persistence for African American adolescents. Finally, the project's partnership with the local school district will increase the possibility for reciprocal relationships in which the research team can continue to learn from those school settings and help address challenges the schools encounter with empirically-based responses.

por.por_cntn:
There is pressing need to understand the effects of stereotypes and stigma upon African American adolescents' development of motivation and identity within the mathematics field. In this project, we used a mixed-methods design to answer the call for more culturally sensitive, gender-attentive, and socially contextualized research on African American achievement motivation. We examined the development of math-related stigma experiences and motivational beliefs, along with how stigma experiences affected motivational beliefs, academic achievement, and STEM aspirations in the context of schools and with teacher and parent influences. The sample was recruited from an ethnically and socioeconomically diverse middle and high school student population.

We conducted interviews and surveys with students to assess math motivation beliefs, experiences of stigma and bias within the climate of school, engagement in math and aspirations for future education in STEM, and perception of influence from teachers and parents. We triangulated student reports with survey data from teachers and parents exploring mindset beliefs about math learning, math teaching and parenting practices, and perceptions of their students' and children's experiences and engagement with math. Finally, video observations captured math classroom climate and teaching practices in real time.

A complementary picture formed between quantitative and qualitative findings regarding the effect of school climate and stereotype beliefs and experiences upon student motivation for math. Collectively, findings provide an understanding of the impacts culturally relevant and developmentally appropriate teaching practice and social justice in mathematics can have among African American students' motivation and academic success. Teaching practices can also improve math identity development and pathways to STEM careers for African American adolescents.

The findings provide insight into best practices for increasing motivation and identity in math. School climate quickly surfaced as an important factor as African American students' responses identified that perceived support for personal culture, values, and practices within the school correlated with increased perceptions of a positive school atmosphere. Teachers' cultural responsiveness also had a large, positive impact on African American students' expectancy for achievement and value of pursing math tasks. Subsequently students with greater value of math also developed a greater math identity. When student-centered teaching practices were used in the classroom, African American students and female identifying students experienced the greatest benefits. Further, when students perceived teaching quality as high, students felt better about their ability to succeed in future math tasks.

Analyses revealed important differences in how African American students' experiences shaped their motivational beliefs and academic success. Across our participants, analyses showed that greater endorsement of a growth mindset was associated with enhanced engagement in math, suggesting that students who adopt growth-oriented beliefs about intelligence exhibit more positive learning trajectories. African American and lower socioeconomic status youth showed endorsement of more fixed views of intelligence, rather than growth views, when compared to their White and higher socioeconomic status peers. Analysis of stereotype beliefs and experiences seem to shed light on why African American students may hold more fixed mindset beliefs. We found that White boys in our sample held the highest stereotype endorsement beliefs about African Americans' math ability, and that African American youth who are aware of these negative academic stereotypes showed less engagement in math classes and greater fixed mindsets over time. Further, stigmatization had a stronger effect on fixed mindsets even in the context of positive in-group beliefs about math ability, meaning that even when African American students knew their African American peers believed in their ability to do well in math, others' negative stereotype beliefs had a stronger hold over their fixed mindsets. However, teacher relationships and practices proved to moderate the relationship between negative stereotypes and mindset beliefs. When math teachers praised African American students for their ability in math classes, the praise moderated the negative impacts of awareness of negative academic stereotypes on student engagement in math classes. This work posits potential for intervening practices teachers can enact to combat the negative effects of the social environment in the school.

Together, findings greatly support the use of culturally relevant pedagogy, examining school and classroom climate, and intervening to support African American students' mindset beliefs, sense of belonging, and culturally specific identity development in mathematics. Our findings have implications for efforts to improve math instruction and increase African American students' motivation in math learning. Results support reforms in math education that emphasize student-centered instruction where students have opportunities to work in groups on authentic and relevant tasks. Teachers should provide students with information about the relevance of math in their daily lives outside of the classroom, the value of math, how math can be used to address social equity issues in their communities, and the historical context of math relevant to their communities. Altogehter, it is important to ensure African American students see that they have skills, abilities, and academic and personal supports needed to be successful in math classrooms.
